projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

2006-08 Olivia BottumText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: THE following Dramatic Trifle, being ſketched in a hurry and intended merely to anſwer a local purpoſe, has nothing to apprehend from the auſterity of Criticiſm; he, who would make a formal attack, upon a dialogue, which aims only to raiſe a laugh at the whimſical incongruities of a few local perplexities, would be the very QUIXOTTE of Critics; and the author of theſe pages would be the laſt to tear a ſingle ſprig from the laurels obtained by ſuch a victory.
ALL IN A BUSTLE: OR THE NEW HOUSE. A COMIC PRELUDE WRITTEN FOR THE OPENING OF THE NEW THEATRE IN NEW-YORK. PERFORMED FOR THE FIRST TIME, ON MONDAY JAN. 29, 1798.
BY WILLIAM MILNS: AUTHOR of the COMET, &c. &c.
NEW-YORK: Printed at the Literary Printing-Office, No. 29, Gold-Street. 1798.

p.hi: The reſt of the Performers perſonate themſelves,

div.head: ALL IN A BUSTLE: OR THE NEW HOUSE.
div.stage: Scene, the Stage, juſt before the doors of the theatre open.

sp.speaker: Prompter.
sp.p: SIR Mr. Hodgkinſon will be here directly.

sp.speaker: Jingle.
sp.p: Hodgkinſon is a good ſtudy is not he?

sp.speaker: Prom.
sp.p: Nobody quicker ſir—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Glad of it—have a few lines here to open the theatre, will immortalize him—

sp.speaker: Prom.
sp.p: Sir he is prepared with an addreſs

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Poo—mere make ſhift—becauſe nothing better was offered him—

sp.speaker: Prom.
sp.p: I am told it is a good thing ſir—written by a gentleman of approved taſte—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Mum for that—not one new idea—lay my exiſtence of it—theſe things are out of your Sphere Mr. Prompter—let him once ſee mine—

sp.speaker: Prom.
sp.p: Here he comes ſir.

sp.speaker: Manager.
sp.p: Mr. Prompter—come—buſtle—we have not a moment to ſpare—who is that? (aſide)

sp.speaker: Prom.
sp.p: A gentleman has brought you ſome lines to open the theatre with

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Damn his lines.

sp.speaker: Prom.
sp.p: No—let the audience do that.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Sir—your moſt obedient—Mr. Hodgkinſon I preſume—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: At your ſervice ſir.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Sir—(takes his hand) I congratulate you on the opening this elegant theatre—I am ſafely arrived, and knowing the barrenneſs of literary talent in this country—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir you miſtake—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Oh—pardon me ſir—policy may dictate excuſes—but mum for that—you know better

sp.speaker: Prom.
sp.p: A modeſt fellow this (aſide)

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: My dear fellow—here—lock yourſelf up ten minutes and ſtudy there—all pith—none of your coarſe frothy ſtuff—whipt ſyllabub every ſyllable:

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir, I've—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Come, come—no excuſes—they'll immortalize you—I know they'll ſucceed—hark'ye; read them to an old woman of ſixty—Moliere's plan you know—an old deaf nurſe where I board—liked them vaſtly—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir I—(eagerly)

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: No apologies between friends—expenſive eſtabliſhment this—want good things—dull ſtuff wont do—increaſe of company—lights expenſive—ſalaries raiſed—people's expectations raiſed—hopes of emolument raiſed.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Yes ſir—and if we ſtand talking here—the gods will be upon us before we are ready: and then there will be the devil of a duſt raiſed—about our ears.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Mr. Hodgkinſon, will you be kind enough to direct me to my dreſſing room—for tho' I've been in it two or three times, I cannot find my way to it.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Go up the ſtaircaſe my dear round that corner—on the ſecond ſtory turn to the left, and you will find a flight of ſtairs; go down them, and yours is the fourth door on the right hand: but be careful which ſtaircaſe you go down, for if you take the wrong, you will loſe yourſelf among the unfiniſhed apartments—the prompter will conduct you.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Here ſir—another jeu d'esprit—a ſerious—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir, I have no leiſure now—my dear do get rid of this poet for me (turns away to give orders to the ſervants who are buſy with the ſcenes.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: I will (ſhe turns to Jingle) Sir, you will excuſe me—but—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: A ſerious prologue Madam; written in quick meaſure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: A ſerious prologue in quick meaſure! very ſingular that.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Yes Madam and a comic epilogue in blank verſe

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: And a comic epilogue in blank verſe! more ſingular ſtill.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: You don't ſee the propriety of that now

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: I do not I confeſs.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: I'm aſtoniſhed—no, I beg pardon—I'm not aſtoniſhed: theſe are errors that a refined taſte only can correct—now Madam—ſhould not a ſerious addreſs he levelled at the paſſions!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Certainly

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: And ſince the paſſions are impetuous the attacks ſhould be violent—and how can that be accompliſhed, but by a rapidity of utterance,—and what but quick meaſure can trip over the tongue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Ingenious at leaſt ſir, if not convincing.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Why are you ladies ſo perſuaſive? why have you ſuch ſuperior hold over the paſſions? my Dear Madam merely from your volubility.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: From our volubility only ſir.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Solely Madam—did you ever know a woman capable of ſitting three minutes comfortably without talking

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: I have known many ſuch ſir

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Muſt have been deaf or dumb then

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: You are very polite ſir

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Facts are ſtubborn things Madam—Experientia docet; nature fore ſaw the evil and out of compaſſion to the ladies, as ſhe gave them ſlippery tongues ſhe left them with ſmooth chins—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you ſir

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Can't you tell Madam why nature refuſed to give the ladies beards

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Beards Sir!

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: I'll tell you Madam—becauſe they can't hold their tongues long enough to be ſhaved

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Upon my word ſir—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: No general rule tho' without an exception—knew two ladies myſelf that had beards—two old maids, one ſixty five, the other ſeventy—eaſily accounted for; time who you know is your greateſt enemy, had robbed them of their teeth, and to prevent diſcovery they impoſed ſilence on their tongues; they ſhut them up in perpetual confinement—ſettled a contract between the noſe and chin, to make the lips do the regular duty of ſtrict jailors—as ſoon as nature perceived the danger of talking was over, ſhe became bountiful, and the harveſt on their chins made ample compenſation for the daurage the mouth had ſuſtained in the loſs of its furniture.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: If your doctrine is true ſir, nature was very ſpiteful in furniſhing your chin; for if you are always as talkative as at preſent your wind pipe muſt have been in frequent danger.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: That's right Madam,—true woman—retort your foibles upon us—here, have you been having all the talk to yourſelf for this half hour

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: I! ſir having all the—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: There again—wont let me put in a word

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: No fear of your having a beard Madam—(he ſees the manager turns ſhort round and follows him) now ſir only give me your patient hearing and I will read one of the principal ſcenes either of a Tragedy, Comedy or Farce—I have them all about me—(takes them out of his pocket pulls out his ſpectacles and puts them on.)

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir, it is impoſſible—you ſee how I am engag'd—if you will leave them at my houſe, I will read them the firſt leiſure moment.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Leave them at your houſe! (ſtareſ at him)

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Yes in Fair Street.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: You wrote the launch, Sir didn't you?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: I did!

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: And you wrote the Man of Fortitude.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: And I ſuppoſe, after you have detained my plays a mouth or two, you would be writing again?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Suppoſe I ſhould?

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Much obliged to you—can't leave my plays with any body—fine thoughts are worth ſtealing—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir, do you ſuſpect!

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Know you would—(pulls off his ſpectacles)

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir—(in a paſſion)

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Author can't help it—do it myſelf—ſteal half my beſt things—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: I dont doubt it—(turns away in a pet)

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: (Turning ſhort to Mrs. Hodg.) pick up a good thought Madam—Strip it of the author's language—dreſs it up in my own—wiredraw it a little for the advantage of weak judgments—and boldly claim the merit of originality.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: But ſuch thefts are eaſily detected, ſir

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Aye by one in a thouſand—Madam thinking is no part of modern authorſhip—the ancients have left us thoughts enough—all we have to do is to hammer them well, and lay them on like modern plate, as thin as poſſible on any courſe materials.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Your ingenuity is equal to your politeneſs.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Took all my pieces to a man who has the general character of a connoiſſeur, but there is no taſte here Madam, would you believe it? he laught at the moſt pathetic parts of my Tragedy; yawn'd and made wry faces during the greater part of the Comedy, and abſolutely went to ſleep all the Farce—there is want of taſte for you Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: But ſir you had better call on Mr. Hodgkinſon To-morrow? I cannot ſtay any longer.

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p:
Take your advice Madam—but heark ye—a word
in your ear—he'll be damn'd mad—that he miſs'd my lines—the fineſt you ever read—only give me five minutes—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Impoſſible ſir—

sp.speaker: Jin.
sp.p: Adieu—call and read them to you another time—but hark'ye ſhan't truſt my pieces out of my own hands—Sir Fretful Plagiary for that, you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Writes himſelf!
sp.stage: (Jingle goes out on one ſide, the manager enters on the other)

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Well, have you got rid of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: With ſome difficulty.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: No matter how—ſo he's gone—Mr. Hughes deſire the ſtage door keeper to admit no ſtranger whatever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: I want to try my voice, let us go thro' a ſhort ſcene.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: It muſt be a ſhort one then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: I'll try an invocation to ſee whether the under tones are diſtinct.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Do—and let it be extempore

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: Reſtore him—merciful Gods (looks to the general box)

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: (Stops ſhort) what do you laugh at?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: My dear you forget where you are, you are not addreſſing the gods—that is the general box, the gods are yonder removed at awful diſtance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: True—I beg their godſhips pardon, well I'll ſuppoſe them there and apologize—pardon high and mighty gods, nor let your thun'dring vengeance fall upon an humble ſuppliant for ſo venial an offence: for tho' my erring eye miſtook the awful ſeat of your abode, my aſpiring heart, on adoration's wings, was ſoaring to approach you gratefully to thank you for every favour paſt, and humbly to implore your future approbation—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Very well my dear, very well

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p:
If I was to addreſs the gods, for one quarter
of an hour, my neck would be ſo ſet, that I ſhould not have the uſe of it again for a month.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Come then I'll tell you how you may try your voice without breaking your neck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Why by ſinging a ſong.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hodg.
sp.p: With all my heart—
sp.l: Great Shakeſpeare come! and ſpread around
Thy magic influence on this ground.
Dear, hollow'd ſhade, on us beſtow
And when thou deign'st to view from high
Each raviſh'd ſoul on wings of fire
Shall riſe thy favour'd choir among.
Hark! hark! 'tis Shakeſpeare ſtrikes the lyre
Awake my ſoul, theſe raptures prove,
From none but HIM ſuch tranſports flow,
His touch can make all boſoms glow,
sp.p: and now I'll go and ſee if I can find my dreſſing room.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Take care you don't miſtake the ſlairs.
sp.stage: Exit. Mrs. Hodg. (A noiſe behind between the Prompter and O'Flaharty.)

sp.speaker: Promp.
sp.p: Sir, I tell you Mr. Hodgkinſon—cannot be ſpoken with.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Boderation honey (puſhes on with his wife) kape your pratty looking daddles off that lady joy▪ or by my ſhoul I'll—Oh your ſarvant ſir—you are not Mr. Hodgkinſon the manager to be ſure now are you?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: I am—but—

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: I did not gueſs that, do you ſee now—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: And pray ſir, who are you?

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Oh!—to be ſure I'm not little Flanagan O'Flaharty—juſt landed, comfortably ſeaked and dry as a ſalt fiſh after a pleaſant journey from dear Tipperary.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: And the lady?

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Oh to be ſure, ſhe is not my wife honey.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: And your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Buſineſs joy!—to be ſure you live in America and can't gueſs now!

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir, it is a buſy time—and I will thank you to tell your buſineſs as briefly as poſſible?

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: As to our buſineſs, look you joy a man of your diſarnment can't ſee that with both your eyes ſhut, why to be ſure our buſineſs is not playing my dear.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: you are actors then?

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: You have hit it honey.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: To deal plainly with you.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Oh don't be after complimenting; as to a choice of parts do ye ſee—we're not too delicate on that head! for my own part, look you—Richard—Macbeth—Lare—Hamlet Benedick—and a few other ſuch characters would do to ſtart with.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir many of thoſe characters I fill myſelf.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Why aye, as you ſay—a New-York audience may have put up with a little makeſhift—but let them once ſee me, my dare—and to be ſure they won't find out the difference—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Oh no doubt.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: And then to ſhew you I'm not unraſonable—you may ſet me down now—for Falſtaff—Wapid—Don Falix—Romeo and Marplot—for ſuch ſecond rate characters to be ſure now little O'Flaharty would not aſtoniſh them—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: But I tell you ſir

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Oh now—dont be apologiſing—my dare—I would not refuſe to play ſuch paltry characters as paping Tom—Lingo or even Shelty—joy—now to be ſure you won't call that condacenſion—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Damn it ſir, I tell you—

sp.speaker: O. Fl.
sp.p: But my dare—don't be for putting me into any of your characters that have nothing to recommend them but the brogue—I never could put the damn'd brogue upon my tongue in my life.

sp.speaker: Manager.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fl.
sp.p: Oh none of your palaver—little O' Flaharty, is not to be humbug'd, my dare—you may give your brogues to thoſe who can't ſpeak pure Engliſh—You may play them yourſelf joy; I'm for your jonteel line honey.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And as for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: For God's ſake, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You may clap me down for Juliet—Lady Macbeth—Beatrice—Lady Townley—Deſdemona—Lady Racket—Alicia—and a few of that ſort of things.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Madam, once for all, I muſt tell you—our company is full, and as for ladies, there are more already than I can poſſibly find parts to ſatisfy.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Now can't you be eaſy.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir—Madam.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Oh, don't be apologizing now.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Damnation—here John—ſhew this Gentleman and Lady the door.
Nay Sir—I have no time.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Suppoſe I give you a fane in Macbeth.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: I will not be interrupted Sir—and if you won't leave me, I muſt leave you. (Going.)

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: How damn'd fond you are of talking my dare; but ſince you will have all the palaver to yourſelf, I'll call on you again to-morrow. Your ſarvant.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Who the devil would be a manager.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: One word, honey.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Damnation.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: You could not lend me five dollars for a few days?

sp.speaker: Manag,
sp.p: I have no money to lend, Sir.

sp.speaker: O'El.
sp.p: I'll pay you out of the profits of my benefit, honey.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Sir I deſire you'll leave me.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: What Sir.—Would you be after putting an affront upon a jontleman?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Leave me Sir.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: Oh, oh, to be ſure, little O'Flaharty wont ſhew you what good breeding is—if you won't engage me, my dear, you ſhall ſight me.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Any thing to get rid of you—any thing another time.

sp.speaker: O'Fl.
sp.p: To be ſure, I wont ſhow you what a coward is.

div.stage: Enter Mrs Collins, followed by Mr Prigmore.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Collins.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Hodgkinſon, why am I canted up into a three pair of ſtairs dreſſing room?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: My dear Madam, I have done all for the beſt, but you ſee it is impoſſible to pleaſe every body.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: Sir, if I am to dance up and down three pair of ſtairs, at every trifling change of dreſs where am I to find breath to go thro' my part?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Madam you muſt be ſatisfied for to night, at leaſt, this is no time to make alterations.

sp.speaker: Mrs. C.
sp.p: As to that, Sir, I am as ſoon ſatisfied as another; but I don't like partialities.

p.hi: During this ſcene, Mr. Prigmore is meaſuring the ſtage, by walking acroſs it.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Well Prig—What are you at now?

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Practiſing the tread of the ſtage. I expect ſome of us, forgetting where we are, ſhall think we have made our exit, before we have half croſs'd it; for inſtance, now in one of my characters—I am ſtanding on this ſide; four ſtrides, and three ſquints at the gallery, at the other theatre, carry me completely off—egad, you ſee, here, it would leave me right in the center.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Well, that would be no bad joke; for you might ſtand and make pretty faces at the gallery: They love to ſee your face, Prig.

sp.speaker: Prig.
sp.p: Make faces at the gallery, that's a good joke—why damme, where would be the uſe of that: at the other houſe, indeed, a well made up face ſtood a chance to be noticed: but here, damme, we ſhall all look like wax-dolls, thro' the diminiſhing end of a teleſcope.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hal.
sp.p: Sir: Mr. Hogg ſays, if the chimney in his dreſſing-room is not altered, he ſhall be ſmoke dried in a month like a ſide of bacon.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: There's a pretty piece of gammon for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Hal.
sp.p: And here's the bill of the coals juſt laid in, Mr. Cant's compliments and you muſt ſend him the money.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Why they an't all deliver'd are they?

sp.speaker: Mr. H.
sp.p: The laſt load came in this afternoon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: He is in a confounded hurry, tell him to call on Mr. Dunlap.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: He ſays he can't wait, he don't like you player folks—he won't have dealing with the unrighteous; he has committed a great ſin in ſelling coals for ſuch an ungodly uſe, and he fears he ſhall be read out of the conventicle for it—he therefore wants the money directly, that he may cloſe the affair, and pacify his conſcience.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Damn his conſcience—tell him he ſhall wait our convenience for his impudence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Johnſon.
sp.p: Mr. Hodgkinſon, do you know that it is within half an hour of the time to open the doors.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Yes—and every body is in a buſtle and nobody ready.

p.hi: Mrs. Johnſon above behind the ſcenes, calls loud, as in a fright.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Johnſon.
sp.p: Mr. Johnſon! Mr. Johnſon!

sp.speaker: Johnſon.
sp.p: Hark!—was not that Mrs. Johnſon's voice?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: It ſounded like it—where can ſhe be?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Johnſon.
sp.p: Mr. Johnſon! (calling again.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Johnſon.
sp.p: My God, is that you—where are you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Johnſon.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Johnſon.
sp.p: Here! where?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Johnſon.
sp.p: I don't know—I have loſt myſelf—

sp.speaker: Mr. Johnſon.
sp.p: Loſt yourſelf—bleſs my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—there ſhe is, in the upper carpenter's gallery.

sp.speaker: Mr. John.
sp.p: How the plague could ſhe get there.

sp.speaker: Prompter.
sp.p: If the carpenters don't alter thoſe bells I ſhall never be able to give the thunder and lightning proper warning.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Then Sir, why did not you look after thoſe things in time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lee
sp.p: Where am I to put all theſe properties, Sir?

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Why in the property room to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lee
sp.p: The property room is full of carpenter's lumber, Sir.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Well, well, don't plague me about it juſt now, put them any where for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeff.
sp.p: All is in confuſion above, Sir. the ſky and the ſea have run foul of each other—the garden ſcene has got entangled over the clouds! and trying to get them looſe the glaſs in the green-houſe has cut off the horns of the new moon, and ſcratched the clouds ſo that they look like flying dumplings.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Why what the devil has got into the people—where are the painters and machiniſts that they don't look better after things?

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeff.
sp.p: They complain that ſo many people go above, they are perpetually hindered, and if a ſtop is not put to it, every thing will be ſpoil'd—The black wench that attends the three pair of ſtairs dreſſing room, has been walking over the new clouds and left all the marks of her feet upon them, ſhe took herſelf for Juno I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: I'll make her find out ſhe is more like Belzebub.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeff.
sp.p: The clouds not being dry down ſhe ſlipt and meaſur'd her whole length—ſmeared the ſeven ſtars and ſwept away half the full moon with her petticoats; in ſcrambling to get up ſhe ſcratched the new Comet ſo unmercifully that it looks like a worn out traveller juſt arrived off a 500 years journey—talk of Juno—Juno never did ſo much miſchief in the heavens with all her ſpite as that wench has done by accident.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Why don't they kick every body down ſtairs that has no buſineſs there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeff.
sp.p: Why ſir, there was Miſs Harding and little Sam Stockwell when I came down, making a ſleigh of Juno's celeſtial Car, which Cicery has juſt finiſh'd painting.
sp.stage: (A great ſcream is heard and the Car is let down)

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: What the devil's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Stockw.
sp.p: The Carpenters have looſened the cords and let us down ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeff.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Thy ſerv'd you right—you had no buſineſs there, faſten the cords Carpenters, leave them where they are till I liberate them—I'll teach them to go a ſleighing in the clouds.
sp.stage: (One of the Carpenters calls out from the upper gallery to another below on the oppoſite ſide.)

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.p: Hallo—Jack.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.p: What do you want.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.p:
Pull the rope belonging to that tackle between the firſt and ſecond entrance—pull it hard and make haſte, ſome
of the gentlemen are waiting for the trunk faſtened to the end of it.

sp.speaker: Carp.
sp.p: I'll trundle it up to you in a jiffy—
sp.stage: (He takes the wrong rope and rings the great bell violently)

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: What the devil are you at now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeff.
sp.p: The thick headed booby has got hold of the bell rope inſtead of the tackle rope.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Do my dear fellow, go and ſtop his noiſe.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Well Jack what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Mart.
sp.p: I've been looking after thoſe things and noſeems to be right,

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Right—why damn me nothing can be right here, every body ſeems to be doing every thing but what they ought to do—the Theatre is like the Tower of Babel, there's nothing but confuſion of tongues in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mart.
sp.p: As the porter was bringing St. Pauls Church upon his ſhoulder, the clumſy dog ran it thro' an Apothecaries window and broke a number of ſhow glaſſes—there ſir St. Paul lies in the ſhop drenched in phyſic, and the apothecary ſwears he will keep St. Paul as a pledge; till you pay the damage.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: I'll forfeit the careleſs raſcal for it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Mart.
sp.p:
And then here's the rain, is ſo dry it rattles no louder than a fall of ſnow—and the lightning is ſo damp it wont flaſh, and the thunder is out of order, it makes no more noiſe than a gentle zephyr, ſo I ſent Tom for the old thunder from the other houſe, his foot ſlipt, the lightning got ſcattered about and is ſo wet that you might as well try to flaſh with a ſnow-ball, the thunder-balls roll'd down a cellar kitchen overſet a black woman's child and tumbled into the teawater caſk, her huſband ſwore the owner of the thunder ſhould pay for the water, for his wife's tongue was too turbulent already, and he'd be dam'd before ſhe ſhould drink thunder water; upon this his wife ſnapt her fingers at
him, dipt a quart mug into it and drank it off, threw a ſecond into her huſband's face—curſed him for a ſneaking blockhead, kick'd one of the thunder balls againſt his ſhins, and threw a handful of lightning in his eyes.

p.hi: A great ſcream is heard behind.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: What next?—

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: What's in the wind now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Jeff.
sp.p: One of the ladies, I won't mention names, dreſſing her hair, her wig I mean, laid it down nicely finiſhed on a chair; who ſhould ſneak in but Chance, Mr. Cooper's dog, and the miſchievous cur taking a fancy to it, walk'd off with it; the lady ſcream'd, Chance took to his heels, and the dreſſers are now in full chace after him to recover the ſtolen property.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tyler.
sp.p: The ſprings of that trap, the man ſays, are ſo weak, that the firſt ghoſt that aſcends, will ſtand a chance to break his neck.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: My dear fellow, that can't be, we'll call the man, and examine it—here John, tell the carpenters to open that trap door.

div.stage: The trap-door opens and as they are looking down Mrs. Tyler calls out below.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tyler.
sp.p: Mr. Hodgkinſon.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: What now, the theatre's haunted, I believe—above, below, we are attacked in every direction.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tyler.
sp.p: It is Mrs. Tyler's ghoſt, I believe, by the voice.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: It comes from below ſure enough what can ſhe be doing there?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tyler.
sp.p: Mr. Hodgkinſon, for God's ſake, ſend ſomebody to get me out.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Get you out Madam! how in the name of wonder got you in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tyler.
sp.p: Coming from my dreſſing room, I miſſed my way I ſuppoſe, for inſtead of getting on the ſtage, I have found my way under it, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Prompter, ring the bell for the trap. (Aſide.) The bell rings and the trap comes up with her upon it. There Tyler, do you think it will bear a ghoſt now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tyler.
sp.p: All my doubts have vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Promp.
sp.p: The doors are opening, Sir.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Down with the curtain then.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tyler.
sp.p: Aye—or like Sampſon, the Philiſtines will be upon us.

sp.speaker: Manag.
sp.p: Every one to his dreſſing room, I'll juſt welcome our old friends in our new houſe, and then follow you.

lg.l: May your brows, oh ye Fair, ne'er with ſorrow be clouded,
And our efforts to pleaſe, keep our boxes thus crouded;
May you, oh ye critics, abounding with out,
Nightly praiſe our attempts from an o'erflowing pit;
Above all, O, ye Gods, we implore without raillery
That your ſmiles and half dollars ſupport our new gallery;
Our beſt talents and time we devote to your will,
That you in return may our treaſury fill;
May our errors ſtill meet with your quick abſolution,
And this theatre thrive like the New Conſtitution.
